resources.string: Walk or run if you flick the stick
Jump, double jump, or footstool if close enough to opponent and currently in the air
Shield/Guard: A bubble that blocks all attacks. It shrinks when hit, becoming less effective. Likely causing a shield-poke.
Spot-dodge - For a short moment evade any attacks or grabs, can be cancelled into attacks earlier than the animation ends

Roll - You are immune to damage only in the middle of the animation as you move left or right. Becomes stale with frequent use. There are punish windows at the beginning and end that grow when stale. \n\nDirectional Airdodge - similar to roll, but can go in 8 directions. (cannot perform any actions until the character falls a set distance after the input)
Jab and jab combo with consecutive presses or holding the button, varies between characters
Tilt attack - Stronger than jab with emphasis on direction chosen. Good for combos and quick punish options
Tilt attack - Stronger than jab with emphasis on direction chosen. Good for combos and quick punish options
Smash attack - Kill move. Similar to tilt attack, but with more startup time and much more knockback potential

Special attack - Signature moves of your character. With certain exceptions, there are 4 per character.\n\nThese can be anything and are a prime example for showing what a character has to offer in terms of strategic options and playstyles.
Grab button or Shield button + Attack button
Grab - Core staple of any fighting game. It goes through shield and allows you to either pummel or throw your opponent in one of 4 directions you input while holding them.

Neutral stages may be chosen in any game of a set, including the first game. These are also referred to as starter stages (not to be confused with the term for stages that do not need to be unlocked to be used in-game). \n\nCounterpick stages may be chosen only after the first game of a set, such as games 2 and 3 of a best-of-3 set. Stages in this category tend to give a slight, though not overwhelming, advantage for certain characters over others, such that it would not be fair to include them in the neutral list. These stages may often (though not always) be chosen for counterpicking purposes, hence the name of the category.

Here you will find examples and explanations of concepts that every pro uses to elevate their game. You only should worry about these if you want to get serious as a competitor. But if you just want to beat your friends, you're still welcome here.

		The most important thing a smasher needs to elevate their play is DI (Directional Influence). This is something you may be using on accident because it feels natural to do. 

		It applies to any hit you take. Any time your opponent knocks you into the air, there's a range of potential angles that you may go as shown in the image below. Smash Ultimate has an incredible training room that will show you the full spectrum on any attack in real-time. Be sure to make use of it.

\t\tTo maximize your influence, consider the path you are being launched and hold your control stick in a direction perpendicular to your trajectory as shown below. Consider where the nearest blast zone is. Using that, decide if you have a higher chance to survive if you give yourself a higher or lower trajectory.

It's not just useful for saving your life on the final hit. It can also cut your opponent's combo short while they attempt to juggle you. If you choose a direction they are not expecting you can potentially escape. When being combo'd at low percents and you're not sure what the safest choice is, just remember : "When in doubt, hold out." 

		After DI, there's SDI(Smash Directional Influence). Think of it as lots of small DI inputs to escape many smaller hits in succession. 

Let's say you're DK in the example below. You want to get out of Little Mac's jab combo by going left. Well, you can't just hold left. The game will only move you once if you do that. 

		So, to make the game accept multiple inputs to the left, you have to change the direction you're pointing on your stick while still pointing the general direction you want to go. Each time you input a different direction, the game will move you accordingly while you're in hitstun.
